Award.AbstractNarration:
In many scientific disciplines, computational simulations form the third pillar of research complementing theory and experiment. With simulations increasing in complexity, resolution and duration, visualization of intermediate results has become important in rapid assessment of simulation data. Moreover with the ubiquity of sensing devices, joint analysis of simulation and observational data is emerging within research communities.

This project capitalizes on recent video standardization strides emerging within web communities. It explores the use,adaptation, and optimization of these video capabilities within the cyberinfrastructure required for advanced computational science. The resulting visualization aims to promote collaboration and facile sharing of scientific results among research and non-research communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SEED project developed and operated a unique and novel prototype cyberinfrastructure that enabled rapid and easy sharing of visualization and other small-scale data on the web. The project developed a system that allowed users to easily transfer, store, describe, discuss, encode videos from a set of visualization images and made them available for playback on various devices with privacy controls to limit access to the shared content. The project not only offered an easy collaboration platform that could be used graphically via a web browser, but also provided users with readily usable web services with corresponding client tools in Python and Java. These scriptable and programmatic tools allowed users an ability to automate and integrate the project cyberinfrastructure with their scientific workflows and applications. The cyberinfrastructure is accessible via its website SeedMe.org.

 

The cyberinfrastructure was well received by a broad and diverse scientific community including astrophysics, climate science, geoscience, mechanical engineering, and structural engineering. Several hundred users have registered and shared over 100,000 visualization and data products during the project period with an expansion in usage and user base continuing. Popular applications such as the Kepler workflow system, OpenMM, Vapor and VisIt software added integrated support for the SeedMe cyberinfrastructure that allowed their users to easily post visualizations and other results directly from the respective applications. In addition to collaboration needs, users also utilized the project for gateways, education and outreach purposes.
